page.title: 02GEOGRAPHICAL FEATURES LEVEN
page.content: The village of Leven is low lying it stands surrounded by fertile agricultural land.The soils are various,gravelly in the higher ground & a loamy,peaty mixture in the low. This is called carrland.The subsoil is chiefly clay.The nature of the soil compostion and the low lying land combined in the past to produce a waterlogged area,but from the middle ages onwards drainage ditches & dykes have been constructed.The village has a criss-crossing pattern of dykes & drains surrounding it, feeding into major drainage works like the River Hull & the Beverley & Barmston drain.This has made the land workable and now it is intensively farmed, the major crops being wheat,barley & oil seed rape with some root crops.Many of the older hedges have been removed to make large fields.
